author: solenskiner
message: I like to have my commits shortly explain what and more importantly why, while the comments explain what in more detail (in case the code is not obvious)

author: Christian Mollekopf
message: I just describe in the commit message why a change has happened if necessary. The code and it's comments should always be sufficient to understand the current state of the code (without browsing git), and if a comment is not necessary for that, I'd probably move it to the commit message.

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: I agree the source should be sufficient to understand the state of the code, but my point is also that commit messages should be sufficient to get an overall understanding of how the code evolved, without requiring reading each diffs.

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: Nice :) That's what I mean with "bad comments can be worse than no comments".

replies.author: lhugs
replies.message: Thats why I refactor a lot, use lengthy variable names and well-known patterns to avoid comments. These come in only for complex algorithms and parallelism

author: Thomas
message: I'd like to add that a commit message can express a doubt, explain how to reproduce the bug, or how it has been tested.
